docs.title: Related Sessions at Cisco Live
docs.text: • BRKXXX-1111 My friend's breakout session

docs.title: Cisco Contact Center + Splunk: How to get Real-Time Data Insights
docs.text: This session focuses on how you can integrate Cisco Contact Centre Enterprise (CCE) with Splunk to gain powerful, real-time, and historical insights into your contact center operations. We'll guide participants through configuring CCE to ingest its reporting data into Splunk. Then, we'll demonstrate how to effectively visualize this data within Splunk, enabling the creation of reports that mirror and enhance standard CCE reporting. Attendees will gain a clear understanding of the CCE-Splunk integration architecture and methods for viewing CCE reports directly within the Splunk platform.

docs.title: Exercise 1 - Existing Stock Report Availability in Splunk
Objective
docs.text: Compare CUIC reports with equivalent Splunk dashboards to demonstrate real-time visibility and data fidelity.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
This exercise demonstrates how Splunk is showing real time data and the existing reports from CCE are already available:

  • Real-time data updates
  • Interactive visualizations
  • Drill-down capabilities

docs.title: Part A: Agent Real-time Report Comparison
Step 1: Access CUIC Agent Real-time Report
docs.text:
1. Login to CUIC
  2. Open CUIC web interface: CUIC login screen - enter your credentials to access the system
  3. After successful login, you will see the CUIC main interface:
  4. Navigate to Reports on left navigation panel CUIC main interface - click on Reports in the left navigation
  5. Search for Agent Real Time report in the search bar.
  6. Click on the Agent Real Time report CUIC Reports search interface showing Agent Real Time report
  7. In the Filter Modal select all agents and click >> icon CUIC filter modal - select all agents and click >> to move them to selected
  8. Click on Run Button
  9. The report will execute and display the agent real-time data: CUIC Agent Real Time report results showing all agent data

docs.title: Step 2: Access Equivalent Splunk Report
docs.text:
1. Login to Splunk
  2. Open Splunk web interface:

  3. After successful login, you will see the Splunk main interface with available apps:

    Splunk main interface - click on CCE Reporting app

  4. Navigate to CCE Reporting app

    Splunk Home Page to Open CCE Reporting App

  5. You will see the Supervisor Dashboard with key metrics:

    Splunk Supervisor Dashboard showing team performance insights

  6. Run Agent Real Time Report

  7. Navigate to Dashboards tab
  8. Under Dashboard tab search for "Agent Real Time" Splunk Dashboards list - search for Agent Real Time
  9. Click on the "Agent Real Time" report link
  10. Splunk will open the Agent Real Time dashboard showing live agent data: Splunk Agent Real Time dashboard showing agent details with real-time status

docs.title: Step 3: Compare Results
docs.text: Compare Results in CUIC and Splunk - Validate if Splunk refreshes the report every 30 seconds and shows fresh data - Validate the data matches with CUIC Reports

docs.title: Part B: Skill Group Status Graphical Real-time
Step 1: Access CUIC Skill Group Status Report
docs.text:
1. Navigate to CUIC Report
  2. Open CUIC web interface.
  3. Navigate to Reports on left navigation panel
  4. Search for Skill Group Status Graphical Real Time report in the search bar.
  5. Click on the Skill Group Status Graphical Real Time report Screenshot of CUIC skill group status graphical report
  6. In the Filter Modal select All Skill Groups and click >> icon
  7. Click on Run Button
Screenshot of CUIC skill group status graphical report Filter Modal Screenshot of CUIC skill group status graphical report

docs.title: Step 2: Access Equivalent Splunk Report
docs.text:
1. Open Splunk web interface

  2. Navigate to CCE Reporting app

  3. Navigate to Dashboards tab

  4. Under Dashboard tab search for "Skill Group Status Graphical Real Time"

  5. Click on the "Skill Group Status Graphical Real Time" report link

    Screenshot of Splunk skill group status graphical report

  6. Select same filter as CUIC Filter and the folowing report should show

    Screenshot of Splunk skill group status graphical report results

docs.title: Step 3: Compare Results
docs.text: Compare Results in CUIC and Splunk - Validate if Splunk refreshes the report every 30 seconds and shows fresh data - Validate the data matches with CUIC Reports and graphs are similar

docs.title: Part C: Agent Team Attendance Historical
Step 1: Access CUIC Agent Team Attendance Historical Report
docs.text:
1. Navigate to CUIC Report
  2. Open CUIC web interface.
  3. Navigate to Reports on left navigation panel
  4. Search for Agent Team Attendance Historical report in the search bar.
  5. Click on the Agent Team Attendance Historical report Screenshot of CUIC team attendance historical report interface
  6. In the Filter Modal select custom date range. Screenshot of CUIC team attendance historical report Filter Custom Date Range
  7. Select a start date which is 7 days ago. Screenshot of CUIC team attendance historical report Filter Custom Date Range Start Date
  8. Select all Agent Teams by clicking on >> button.
  9. Click on Run Button Screenshot of CUIC team attendance historical report Filter Custom Date Range Start Date Screenshot of CUIC team attendance historical report Filter Custom Date Range Start Date

docs.title: Step 2: Access Equivalent Splunk Report
docs.text:
1. Login to Splunk
  2. Open Splunk web interface
  3. Navigate to CCE Reporting app
  4. Navigate to Dashboards tab
  5. Under Dashboard tab search for "Agent Team Attendance Historical"
  6. Click on the "Agent Team Attendance Historical" report link Screenshot of Splunk team attendance historical report
  7. Select same date range and team filters as CUIC Filter (by default last 7 days is selected) and the following report should show Screenshot of Splunk team attendance historical report results
  8. Click on the 1st row to drill-down Screenshot of Splunk team attendance historical report results

docs.title: Step 3: Compare Results and Drill-down Capabilities
docs.text: Compare Results in CUIC and Splunk: - Validate the attendance data matches between CUIC and Splunk reports - Test drill-down functionality in Splunk to get detailed agent information - Validate historical data accuracy for the selected date range

docs.title: Key Comparisons Completed
docs.text:
1. Agent Real-time Report: Real-time agent status and state information
  2. Skill Group Status Graphical Real-time: Queue and service level monitoring
  3. Agent Team Attendance Historical: Historical attendance and productivity data

docs.title: Benefits Demonstrated
docs.text:
• Data Fidelity: Splunk shows the same accurate data as CUIC reports
  • Real-time Updates: Splunk provides automatic refresh capabilities
  • Enhanced Visualization: More interactive and drill-down options

docs.title: Exercise 2 - Building Dashboards with Dashboard Studio
Objective
docs.text: Create a focused, interactive dashboard using Splunk's Dashboard Studio to provide real-time visibility into key contact center operations with two essential visualizations.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
This exercise demonstrates how to build an operational dashboard using Dashboard Studio that provides:

  • Real-time queue monitoring with column charts
  • Agent performance tracking with bar charts
  • Modern, responsive dashboard interface

docs.title: Part A: Create Dashboard Studio Dashboard
Step 1: Create New Dashboard Studio Dashboard
docs.text:
1. Access Dashboard Studio
  2. Navigate to Apps > CCE Reporting > Dashboards
  3. Click Create New Dashboard
  4. Dashboard Title: "Contact Center Operations Dashboard"
  5. Description: "Real-time contact center monitoring with key metrics"
  6. Select Dashboard Studio (not Classic Dashboard)
  7. Select Grid
  8. Click Create
Screenshot showing Dashboard Studio Configuration

docs.title: Step 2: Configure Dashboard Settings
docs.text:
1. Set Dashboard Properties
  2. Navigate to Edit mode in Dashboard Studio
  3. Set Default Time Range: Last 24 hours

docs.title: Part B: Calls Queued Now - Bar Chart
Step 1: Add Bar Chart Visualization
docs.text:
1. Create New Visualization Panel

  2. Click + Add Chart in Dashboard Studio

  3. Select Bar Chart from visualization types

Screenshot showing Dashboard Studio Configuration

Screenshot showing Dashboard Studio Configuration
  1. Configure Data Source Query
  2. Under search in Select data source click on Create search link.

Screenshot showing Dashboard Studio creation interface

Screenshot showing Dashboard Studio Configuration
  • Enter
index=cce_rt sourcetype="cce:rt:precision_q_real_time" 
| stats latest(*) as * by PrecisionQueueID 
| where CallsOfferedTo5 > 0
| join type=left PrecisionQueueID
    [ search index=cce_config sourcetype=cce:config:precision_queue earliest=1
    | fields PrecisionQueueID EnterpriseName
    | rename  EnterpriseName as PrecisionQueueName ]
| eval CallsOffered = CallsOfferedTo5
| eval AnswerWaitTime = AnswerWaitTimeTo5
| table PrecisionQueueName CallsOffered AnswerWaitTime
| rename PrecisionQueueName as "Precision Queue", CallsOffered as "Calls Offered", AnswerWaitTime as "Answer Wait Time(secs)" 

- Under source coded section add refresh:30s in options

json "options": { "query": "index=cce_rt sourcetype=cce:rt:skill_group_real_time\n| stats latest(*) as * by SkillTargetID\n| where RouterCallsQNow > 0\n| join type=left SkillTargetID\n [ search index=cce_config sourcetype=cce:config:skill_group earliest=1\n | fields SkillTargetID EnterpriseName\n | rename EnterpriseName as SkillGroupName ]\n| eval QueuedCalls = RouterCallsQNow\n| eval LongestCallWaiting = now()-RouterLongestCallInQ/1000\n| table SkillGroupName QueuedCalls LongestCallWaiting\n| sort -QueuedCalls\n| rename SkillGroupName as \"Skill Group\", QueuedCalls as \"Calls in Queue\", LongestCallWaiting as \"Longest Wait Time\"", "refresh":"30s" },

Screenshot showing Dashboard Studio Configuration 
- Click on Apply and close
- Under Data Configuration Section Select
    - Select Skill Group for X
    - Calls in Queue and Longest Wait Time for Y
    - Longest Wait Time in Y2

Screenshot showing Dashboard Studio Configuration

docs.title: Part C: Agent Performance Leaderboard - Column Chart
Step 1: Create Performance Data Query
docs.text:
1. Add New Column Chart Visualization

  2. Click + Add Chart

  3. Select Column Chart
  4. Title: "Top 10 Agent Performance (Last 24 Hours)"

  5. Position below the column chart

  6. Configure Performance Query

  7. Under search in Select data source click on Create search link.

  8. Enter
index=cce_hds sourcetype="cce:hds:agent_interval"
| join type=left SkillTargetID
    [ search index=cce_config sourcetype=cce:config:agent earliest=1
    | fields SkillTargetID PersonID
    ]
| join type=left PersonID
    [ search index=cce_config sourcetype=cce:config:person earliest=1
    | eval AgentName = LastName . ", " . FirstName
    | fields PersonID AgentName
    ]
| join type=left SkillTargetID DateTime
    [ search index=cce_hds sourcetype=cce:hds:agent_skill_group_interval earliest=-24h@h latest=now
    | where CallsHandled > 0
    | fields SkillTargetID DateTime CallsHandled HandledCallsTime
    ]
| stats sum(CallsHandled) as TotalCalls sum(HandledCallsTime) as TotalHandleTime by AgentName SkillTargetID
| where TotalCalls > 0
| eval AHT = round(TotalHandleTime / TotalCalls, 0)
| eval AHT_Minutes = round(AHT / 60, 1)
| eval AHT_Formatted = tostring(AHT, "duration")
| eval Efficiency_Score = round((TotalCalls * 100) / (TotalCalls + AHT_Minutes), 1)
| sort -TotalCalls
| streamstats count as Rank
| table Rank AgentName TotalCalls AHT
| rename Rank as "#",
    AgentName as "Agent Name",
    TotalCalls as "Calls Handled",
    AHT as "Avg Handle Time"

- Click on Apply and close
- Under Data Configuration Section Select
    - Select Agent Name for X
    - Agent Name, Calls Handled and Average Handle Time for Y
    - Average Handle Time in Y2

Screenshot of agent performance data query

docs.title: What You've Accomplished
docs.text:
• ✅ Built real-time queue monitoring with 30-second auto-refresh for immediate visibility
  • ✅ Implemented agent performance leaderboard showing top performers over 24-hour periods
  • ✅ Configured dual-axis visualizations combining call volume and wait time metrics
  • ✅ Established responsive dashboard layout optimized for different screen sizes

docs.title: Key Benefits
docs.text:
• Modern User Interface: Dashboard Studio provides enhanced visual appeal and better user experience
  • Real-time Monitoring: 30-second refresh ensures supervisors see current queue status
  • Performance Visibility: Agent leaderboard promotes healthy competition and recognition
  • Dual Metrics Display: Column charts show both primary and secondary KPIs simultaneously
  • Mobile Responsive: Dashboards automatically adapt to different devices and screen sizes

docs.title: Exercise 3 - Alerting for Agent Not Ready Duration
Objective
docs.text: Implement proactive alerting in Splunk to monitor agents who have been in "Not Ready" state for more than 5 minutes and automatically notify supervisors when this threshold is breached.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
This exercise demonstrates how to create an intelligent alert that:

  • Monitors real-time agent states
  • Detects when agents remain in "Not Ready" state for extended periods
  • Sends automated notifications with contextual information
  • Helps supervisors take immediate corrective action
  • Improves overall agent productivity and availability

docs.title: Part A: Agent Not Ready Duration Alert
Step 1: Create Not Ready State Alert
docs.text:
1. Access Splunk Alert Creation
  2. Navigate to Settings > Searches, reports, and alerts
Screenshot showing alert trigger creation
  • Click New Alert
Screenshot showing alert trigger creation

docs.title: Step 2: Configure Not Ready Duration Alert
docs.text:
• Enter title as Agent Not Ready Alert
  • Enter the SPL
index=cce_rt sourcetype=cce:rt:agent_real_time
| stats latest(*) as * by SkillTargetID
| where operation != "D"
| where AgentState == 2
| eval CurrentTime = now()
| eval StateChangeTime = DateTimeLastStateChange/1000
| eval StateChangeTime_fmt = strftime(StateChangeTime, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S.%3N")
| eval NotReadyDuration = CurrentTime - StateChangeTime
| where NotReadyDuration > 300
| join type=left SkillTargetID
    [ search index=cce_config sourcetype=cce:config:agent earliest=1
    | fields SkillTargetID PersonID ]
| join type=left PersonID
    [ search index=cce_config sourcetype=cce:config:person earliest=1
    | eval AgentName = LastName . ", " . FirstName
    | fields PersonID AgentName LoginName ]
| join type=left ReasonCode
    [ search index=cce_config sourcetype=cce:config:reason_code earliest=1
    | fields ReasonCode ReasonText ]
| eval NotReadyMinutes = round(NotReadyDuration / 60, 1)
| eval AlertMessage = "Agent " . AgentName . " (" . LoginName . ") has been in Not Ready state for " . NotReadyMinutes . " minutes"
| eval ReasonDescription = if(isnull(ReasonText) OR ReasonText == "", "No Reason Code", ReasonText)
| table AlertMessage AgentName LoginName SkillGroupName ReasonDescription NotReadyMinutes StateChangeTime_fmt
| sort -NotReadyMinutes
| rename AgentName as "Agent Name",
    LoginName as "Login Name",
    ReasonDescription as "Reason Code",
    NotReadyMinutes as "Duration (Minutes)",
    StateChangeTime_fmt as "State Change Time"
Screenshot showing alert trigger condition settings

docs.title: Step 3: Configure Alert Timing and Schedule
docs.text:
1. Set Alert Timing

  2. Alert Type: Scheduled & "Run on Cron Schedule"

  3. Cron Expression: */5 * * * * (Run every 5 minutes)

Screenshot showing alert trigger condition settings

docs.title: Step 4: Configure Alert Trigger Conditions
docs.text:
1. Set Trigger Condition
  2. Trigger Condition: Number of Results
  3. Condition: is greater than 0
  4. Once: Enable (Send separate alert for each agent)
  5. Add Actions and select Add to Triggered Alerts
Screenshot showing alert trigger condition settings Screenshot showing alert trigger condition Created

docs.title: Step 5: Test and Validate Alert
docs.text:
1. Test Alert Configuration
  2. Click Save Alert
Screenshot showing alert trigger condition Created
  • Monitor for the next few minutes
  • Verify the alerts are coming in by checking alerts in Activity > Triggered Alerts
Screenshot showing alert test execution results

docs.title: What You've Accomplished
docs.text:
• ✅ Created focused Not Ready duration alert for agents exceeding 5-minute threshold
  • ✅ Implemented automated email notifications with rich contextual information
  • ✅ Configured per-result alerting to handle multiple agents simultaneously

docs.title: Key Benefits
docs.text:
• Proactive Management: Automatic detection of productivity issues before they impact service
  • Rapid Response: Immediate notifications enable swift supervisor intervention
  • Operational Efficiency: Reduced manual monitoring overhead frees supervisors for strategic tasks

docs.title: Exercise 3 - Alerting for Agent Not Ready Duration
Exercise 3 - Alerting for Agent Not Ready Duration
Objective
docs.text: Implement proactive alerting in Splunk to monitor agents who have been in "Not Ready" state for more than 5 minutes and automatically notify supervisors when this threshold is breached.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
This exercise demonstrates how to create an intelligent alert that:

  • Monitors real-time agent states
  • Detects when agents remain in "Not Ready" state for extended periods
  • Sends automated notifications with contextual information
  • Helps supervisors take immediate corrective action
  • Improves overall agent productivity and availability

docs.title: Part A: Agent Not Ready Duration Alert
Step 1: Create Not Ready State Alert
docs.text:
1. Access Splunk Alert Creation
  2. Navigate to Settings > Searches, reports, and alerts
  3. Click New Alert
  4. Choose CCE Reporting app

docs.title: Step 2: Configure Not Ready Duration Alert
docs.text:
• Enter title as Agent Not Ready Alert
  • Enter the SPL
index=cce_rt sourcetype=cce:rt:agent_real_time
| stats latest(*) as * by SkillTargetID
| where operation != "D"
| where AgentState == 2
| eval CurrentTime = now()
| eval StateChangeTime = DateTimeLastStateChange/1000
| eval StateChangeTime_fmt = strftime(StateChangeTime, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S.%3N")
| eval NotReadyDuration = CurrentTime - StateChangeTime
| where NotReadyDuration > 300
| join type=left SkillTargetID
    [ search index=cce_config sourcetype=cce:config:agent earliest=1
    | fields SkillTargetID PersonID ]
| join type=left PersonID
    [ search index=cce_config sourcetype=cce:config:person earliest=1
    | eval AgentName = LastName . ", " . FirstName
    | fields PersonID AgentName LoginName ]
| join type=left ReasonCode
    [ search index=cce_config sourcetype=cce:config:reason_code earliest=1
    | fields ReasonCode ReasonText ]
| eval NotReadyMinutes = round(NotReadyDuration / 60, 1)
| eval AlertMessage = "Agent " . AgentName . " (" . LoginName . ") has been in Not Ready state for " . NotReadyMinutes . " minutes"
| eval ReasonDescription = if(isnull(ReasonText) OR ReasonText == "", "No Reason Code", ReasonText)
| table AlertMessage AgentName LoginName SkillGroupName ReasonDescription NotReadyMinutes StateChangeTime_fmt
| sort -NotReadyMinutes
| rename AgentName as "Agent Name",
    LoginName as "Login Name",
    ReasonDescription as "Reason Code",
    NotReadyMinutes as "Duration (Minutes)",
    StateChangeTime_fmt as "State Change Time"
Screenshot showing alert trigger condition settings

docs.title: Step 3: Configure Alert Timing and Schedule
docs.text:
1. Set Alert Timing

  2. Alert Type: Scheduled

  3. Cron Expression: */5 * * * * (Run every 5 minutes)
  4. Earliest time: -1m (Look back 1 minute)
  5. Latest time: now

docs.title: Step 4: Configure Alert Trigger Conditions
docs.text:
1. Set Trigger Condition
  2. Trigger Condition: Number of Results
  3. Condition: is greater than 0
  4. Once: Enable (Send separate alert for each agent)
  5. Add Actions and select Add to Triggered Alerts
Screenshot showing alert trigger condition settings

docs.title: Step 5: Test and Validate Alert
docs.text:
1. Test Alert Configuration
  2. Click Save Alert
  3. Monitor for the next few minutes
  4. Verify the alerts are coming in by checking alerts in Activity > Triggered Alerts

docs.title: What You've Accomplished
docs.text:
• ✅ Created focused Not Ready duration alert for agents exceeding 5-minute threshold
  • ✅ Implemented automated email notifications with rich contextual information
  • ✅ Configured per-result alerting to handle multiple agents simultaneously

docs.title: Key Benefits
docs.text:
• Proactive Management: Automatic detection of productivity issues before they impact service
  • Rapid Response: Immediate notifications enable swift supervisor intervention
  • Operational Efficiency: Reduced manual monitoring overhead frees supervisors for strategic tasks

docs.title: Exercise 4 - Utilizing Machine Learning for Call Forecasting and Anomaly Detection
Objective
docs.text: Implement advanced machine learning capabilities in Splunk to predict call volumes, detect anomalies, and provide intelligent insights for contact center optimization.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
This exercise demonstrates how to leverage Splunk's Machine Learning Toolkit (MLTK) to:

  • Build predictive models for call forecasting
  • Detect unusual patterns and anomalies
  • Enable data-driven decision making

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
1. Splunk AI Toolkit is Installed
  2. For this exercise the App is already installed

docs.title: Part A: Build Call Forecasting Model Based on Historical Data
Step 1: Build Time Series Forecasting Model
docs.text:
1. Access AI Toolkit for Forecasting

  2. Navigate to AI Toolkit app, by clicking on the Apps dropdown

Screenshot showing AI Toolkit App
  • Click Experiments > Forecast Time Series

Screenshot showing opening Experiments tab
  • Click Create New Experiment

Screenshot showing Forecast Time Series
  • Select Forecast Time Series as experiment type and enter any experiment title

Screenshot showing Forecast Time Series
  1. Configure Experiment Settings
  2. Enter SPL
index="cce_demo"
| eval _time = strptime(DateTime, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S")
| timechart span=15m sum(CallsOffered) as TotalCallsOffered
| makecontinuous _time span=15m
| fillnull value=0

Screenshot showing Forecast Time Series SPL
  • Under Algorithm Select Kalman Filter
  • Select TotalCallsOffered in Field to forecast
  • Select LLP5 as method
  • Enter 700 for Future Timespan and Holdback
  • Enter confidence interval as 95
  • Enter 672 as period

Screenshot showing Forecast Time Series Configuration

docs.title: Step 2: Generate and Validate Forecast
docs.text:
1. Run Forecasting Model

  2. Click on Forecast Button

  3. Observe forecasting results are shown as in image

Screenshot showing Forecast Time Series Graph

docs.title: Step 3: Schedule Forecast Retraining
docs.text:
1. Schedule Configuration
  2. Click on Open in Search Buton
  3. Ensure the SPL shows the parameter selected
  4. Click on Save As Report
Screenshot showing Forecast Time Series Scheduling
  • Enter the title as "Scheduled Call Forecast Training" and click Save
Screenshot showing Forecast Time Series Scheduling
  • In the next popup click on Schedule and Click on View
Screenshot showing Forecast Time Series Scheduling
  • Click on the Schedule Report and configure it to Run Every Week Monday 6:00
  • Click Save
Screenshot showing Forecast Time Series Scheduling

docs.title: Part B: Anomaly Detection for Call Patterns
Step 1: Configure Numeric Outlier Detection
docs.text:
1. Access AI Experiments
  2. Navigate to AI Toolkit > Experiments
Screenshot showing opening Experiments tab
  • Click Create New Experiment
Screenshot showing Creating new experiment
  • Choose Detect Numeric Outliers as experiment type and enter any experiment title
Screenshot showing Creating new experiment

docs.title: Step 2: Configure Experiment Settings
docs.text:
1. Enter SPL Query for Anomaly Detection
index="cce_demo"
| eval _time = strptime(DateTime, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S")
| timechart span=15m sum(CallsOffered) as CallsOffered by SkillGroup
| untable _time SkillGroup CallsOffered
| streamstats window=96 avg(CallsOffered) as avg stdev(CallsOffered) as stdev by SkillGroup
| eval upper_bound = avg + (3 * stdev)
| eval is_anomaly = if(CallsOffered > upper_bound AND CallsOffered > 50, 1, 0)
and click on Search Screenshot showing Outlier Detection SPL

  1. Configure Outlier Detection Parameters

  2. Select CallsOffered as the field to analyze for outliers

  3. Under Threshold Method select Standard Deviation
  4. Set threshold multiplier to 3
  5. Select SkillGroup as the field to split by

Screenshot showing Outlier Detection Configuration

docs.title: Step 3: Run Outlier Detection Analysis
docs.text:
1. Execute Outlier Detection
  2. Click on Detect Outliers Button
  3. Observe anomaly detection results showing skill groups with abnormal call patterns
  4. Review the outlier scores and identified anomalies
Screenshot showing Outlier Detection Graphs

docs.title: Step 4: Schedule Anomaly Detection Retraining
docs.text:
1. Create Scheduled Report
  2. Click on Open in Search Button
  3. Ensure the SPL shows the parameters selected in the experiment
  4. Click on Save As Report
Screenshot showing Outlier Detection Report
  • Enter the title as "Scheduled Call Pattern Anomaly Detection" and Click Save
Screenshot showing Outlier Detection Report
  • In the next popup click on Schedule and View Button
Screenshot showing Outlier Detection Schedule
  • Click on the Schedule Report and configure it to Run Every Day at 2:00 AM
  • Click Save
Screenshot showing Outlier Detection Schedule

docs.title: What You've Accomplished
docs.text:
• ✅ Implemented time series forecasting using Splunk MLTK for call volume prediction
  • ✅ Built automated anomaly detection system using LocalOutlierFactor algorithm
  • ✅ Created scheduled model retraining for both forecasting and anomaly detection

docs.title: Key Benefits
docs.text:
• Predictive Intelligence: Forecast call volumes 3 days in advance for better planning
  • Automated Anomaly Detection: Real-time identification of unusual call patterns
  • Self-Maintaining Models: Scheduled retraining keeps models current with data trends
  • Proactive Management: Early warning system for operational issues

docs.title: Lab Session Access
docs.text:
To access your lab session, please open the following URL:

Lab Session | Workstation 1 Setup

Click the link above to access your dedicated lab environment. This will open your lab session where you can follow along with the exercises. 🔗 Open Lab Session (click here)

  1. Once you open the above link, you will redirected to the below screen. Click on Explore.
  2. Enter your Email address and check the terms and condition to start the lab.
  3. Open both Work Station 1 & 2, by clicking on the Remote Desktop links.
  4. In Work Station 1, Start the "Start Call Simulator.bat" file.
  5. Click okay on the pop-up and leave 'Work Station 1' alone as it simulates calls data on which we will perform later on.

docs.title: Lab Prerequisites
docs.text:
Come to Workstation 2 Before starting this lab, you'll need to download and install the required Splunk app package:

Download

https://webexcc-sa.github.io/LAB-2323/assets/cce-splunk-reports-1.0.0-app.tar

  1. Copy the Download URL mentioned above.
  2. Open Workstation 2.
  3. Paste the download URL in Workstation 2 chrome browser. This will download cce-splunk-reports-1.0.0-app.tar file in Workstation 2's Downloads folder.

  4. Open Splunk in Workstation 2 Chrome and Login.

    Splunk Access Point & Credentials

    Key Value URL https://198.18.133.1:8000/en-US/app/launcher/home Username dclouduser Password dcloud@123

    5. Navigate to Manage Apps page.

    6. Click on Install App from file. 7. Browse the recently downloaded file from the downloads folder and upload it. 8. Come to Splunk's home page, and newly installed CCE Reporting Splunk App will be visible under Splunk.

docs.title: Splunk Access
docs.text:
Key Value URL https://198.18.133.1:8000/en-US/app/launcher/home Username dclouduser Password dcloud@123

When you access the Splunk URL, you should see the Splunk Enterprise login screen:

Splunk Enterprise login interface - enter your dclouduser credentials

docs.title: CUIC Access
docs.text:
Key Value URL https://cuic1.dcloud.cisco.com:8444/cuicui/Main.jsp Username administrator Password C1sco12345

When you access the CUIC URL, you should see the Cisco Unified Intelligence Center login screen:

CUIC login interface - enter your administrator credentials

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: This lab leverages Cisco dCloud ...

docs.title: Akshat Atray
docs.text:
Software Engineer, Cisco

About Akshat Atray Akshat Atray is a developer at Cisco, working on the Cisco Unified Intelligence Center (CUIC) within the Contact Center Enterprise (CCE) suite. With experience across the stack, he focuses on modernizing systems, improving user experiences, and building scalable, maintainable software. He frequently speaks on AI, system design, accessibility, and app development. Outside work, Akshat enjoys football, photography, painting, and traveling.

docs.title: Senthilkumar Thangavel
docs.text:
Lead Engineer, Cisco

About Senthilkumar Thangavel I am lead engineer at Cisco, known for their deep understanding of contact center reporting. I have spent my time Cisco leveraging platforms like Cisco Unified Intelligence Center and Live Data to empower businesses with the data they need to improve customer experience and operational efficiency. My work helps make sense of the vast amounts of information generated by modern contact centers.

docs.text:

docs.title: Adding a Copy Button Without a Code Block
docs.text:
This will copy the following text: <copy>Text to copy</copy>

This will copy the following text: Text to copy

docs.title: Adding user specific variables into your lab guide
docs.text: There may be times in which you want to embed some attendee specific information into the instructions of your lab guide, like credentials or phone numbers, which will be used on multiple pages of your lab guide. You can gather the information via a form or you can pass a pre-encoded JSON string as a URL parameter to populate the variable values into the browser's session storage. Then you can use a simple HTML tag with a special class name to update the values in the lab guide. This feature can be combined with the copy button method above.

docs.title: Form Method
URL Method
docs.text:
If you have a lot of attendee variables in your lab, you may choose to precompile and encode them so that you can simply provide a URL link which will load all of their required information.

To see this in action, add this string at the end of the URL for any page on this site: ?eyJBZG1pbiI6ImFkbWluQHh5ei5iaXoiLCJQVyI6InNVcGVyU2VjcmV0MTIzISIsIkVQIjoiRVAxIiwiRE4iOiIrMTkxMDU1NTEyMTUyIiwiUXVldWUiOiJRdWV1ZTEiLCJRdWV1ZTIiOiJRdWV1ZTIiLCJUZWFtIjoiVGVhbTEiLCJUZWFtMiI6IlRlYW0yIn0=

docs.title: Initial Setup
docs.text: This lab guide template uses MKDocs to take your markdown documentation and transform it into an interactive web based lab guide. You will need to install some software on your PC or Mac in order to take full advantage of the tool which will allow you to view your changes as you save them and ensure that your formatting is exactly how you want it.

docs.title: Prerequisite Software to Install
docs.text:
1. Python
  2. Visual Studio Code
  3. Git

docs.title: Setting up your lab guide on your computer
Clone your repository with git
docs.text:
Open Visual Studio Code

Click the Source Control button in the left menu

Click Clone Repository

Enter the repository source: https://github.com/WebexCC-SA/WebexCC-SA/LAB-2323.git

Select or create a new folder to clone the repository into.

docs.title: Build the environment
docs.text:
When prompted to open the cloned repository, select open.

Drag open the terminal at the bottom of the Visual Studio Code window

Show Me

If you are on a PCIf you are on a Mac

In your terminal enter the following commands:

python -m venv venv

Set-ExecutionPolicy -ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned -Scope CurrentUser

venv\Scripts\activate.ps1

pip install -r requirements.txt

mkdocs serve

Open a browser to http://127.0.0.1:8000

In your terminal enter the following commands:

python -m venv venv

source venv/bin/activate

pip install -r requirements.txt

mkdocs serve

Open a browser to http://127.0.0.1:8000

docs.title: Using the tool after the initial setup
Using the tool after the initial setup
docs.text:
After the initial setup you will only need to take the following steps:

Open Visual Studio Code

Click the Source Control button in the left menu

Click Open Folder and navigate to the folder where you cloned the repository

If you are on a PCIf you are on a Mac

In your terminal enter the following commands:

venv\Scripts\activate.ps1

mkdocs serve

Open a browser to http://127.0.0.1:8000

In your terminal enter the following commands:

source venv/bin/activate

mkdocs serve

Open a browser to http://127.0.0.1:8000

docs.text:
https://www.markdownguide.org/cheat-sheet/

https://github.com/lifeparticle/Markdown-Cheatsheet

docs.title: Publishing Your Changes
docs.text: As you progress with the creation of your lab guide, you should sync your changes periodically to GitHub.

docs.title: Syncing your changes to GitHub
docs.text:
Make sure that you have saved all of the files you want to sync up to the repository

Click the Source Control button in the left menu

Click the plus sign next to each file you want to sync as you hover over the file names or alternatively, click the plus sign next to changes

Enter a note about the changes you are making in the message text box

Click the down chevron on the commit button to reveal more options

Select Commit & Sync

docs.title: After you Sync your changes, it will take a few minutes for GitHub Actions to build the website so that you can view all of the changes you made.
